← Previous revision Revision as of 11:44, 8 February 2026
Line 62: Line 62:
[[File:Ickenham Festival in the grounds of Swakeleys House.JPG|thumb|right|The 2010 Ickenham Festival within the grounds of the house]]
[[File:Ickenham Festival in the grounds of Swakeleys House.JPG|thumb|right|The 2010 Ickenham Festival within the grounds of the house]]
Three local residents, Keith Chamberlain, Paul Newson and Simon Kreiger, formed Swakeleys House Ltd as a non-profit company to purchase the house in 1980 following a long period of deterioration. They then restored its key features and constructed new office buildings within the grounds to help finance the restoration works. In 1984, a 25-year lease was negotiated with the [[Bristol-Myers Squibb]] company and the house was opened to the public for three days a year.<ref>Bowlt 1996, p.23</ref> [[His Royal Highness|HRH]] [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Prince Philip]] the Duke of Edinburgh officially opened the newly refurbished house on 7 May 1985. Swakeleys House Ltd went on to win the 1988 Country House Award for best conversion of a listed country house.<ref name="Skinner"/>
Three local residents, Keith Chamberlain, Paul Newson and Simon Kreiger, formed Swakeleys House Ltd as a non-profit company to purchase the house in 1980 following a long period of deterioration. They then restored its key features and constructed new office buildings within the grounds to help finance the restoration works. In 1984, a 25-year lease was negotiated with the [[Bristol-Myers Squibb]] company and the house was opened to the public for three days a year.<ref>Bowlt 1996, p.23</ref> [[His Royal Highness|HRH]] [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Prince Philip]] the Duke of Edinburgh officially opened the newly refurbished house on 7 May 1985. Swakeleys House Ltd went on to win the 1988 Country House Award for best conversion of a listed country house.<ref name="Skinner"/>

In 1967, the opening cricket scene of Carry On Follow that Camel was filmed on the grounds.


During 2012, scenes for the film ''[[Great Expectations (2012 film)|Great Expectations]]'',<ref>{{cite web |last1=Porter |first1=Laura |title=Great Expectations Filming Locations |url=https://aboutlondonlaura.com/great-expectations-filming-locations/ |website=About London Laura |access-date=15 October 2022 |date=26 May 2016}}</ref> and the television adaptation of ''[[Mr Stink]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://filmlondon.org.uk/filming_in_london/locations_crew_facilities/locations/location_of_the_month_2012/december2012 |title=December 2012 – Film London |date=December 2012 |publisher=Film London |access-date=21 April 2013}}</ref> were filmed within the house.
During 2012, scenes for the film ''[[Great Expectations (2012 film)|Great Expectations]]'',<ref>{{cite web |last1=Porter |first1=Laura |title=Great Expectations Filming Locations |url=https://aboutlondonlaura.com/great-expectations-filming-locations/ |website=About London Laura |access-date=15 October 2022 |date=26 May 2016}}</ref> and the television adaptation of ''[[Mr Stink]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://filmlondon.org.uk/filming_in_london/locations_crew_facilities/locations/location_of_the_month_2012/december2012 |title=December 2012 – Film London |date=December 2012 |publisher=Film London |access-date=21 April 2013}}</ref> were filmed within the house.

==Marriage and issue==
==Marriage and issue==
About 14 BC, Appianus married [[Claudia Marcella Minor]], a daughter of [[Octavia the Younger]]; Claudia Marcella Minor's maternal uncle was the [[Roman emperor]] Augustus.<ref name=Lightman-205/> Marcella bore Appianus two children, a daughter [[Claudia Pulchra]] and a son [[Marcus Valerius Messalla Barbatus (consul 20)|Marcus Valerius Messalla Barbatus]].<ref name=Syme-147/><ref name=Lightman-205/> Although there has been some speculation that Claudia's father might actually have been [[Publius Claudius Pulcher (son of Clodius)|Publius Claudius Pulcher]], the son of [[Publius Clodius Pulcher|Clodius]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Augustan Aristocracy|last=Syme|first=Ronald|publisher=Clarendon Press|year=1989|isbn=9780198147312|pages=149|edition=new, illustrated, reworked|series=Clarendon paperbacks|chapter=Two Nieces of Augustus}}</ref>
About 14 BC, Appianus married [[Claudia Marcella Minor]], a daughter of [[Octavia the Younger]]; Claudia Marcella Minor's maternal uncle was the [[Roman emperor]] Augustus.<ref name=Lightman-205/> Marcella bore Appianus two children: a daughter, [[Claudia Pulchra]], and a son, [[Marcus Valerius Messalla Barbatus (consul 20)|Marcus Valerius Messalla Barbatus]],<ref name=Lightman-205/><ref name=Syme-147/> although there has been some speculation that Claudia's father might actually have been [[Publius Claudius Pulcher (son of Clodius)|Publius Claudius Pulcher]], the son of [[Publius Clodius Pulcher|Clodius]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Augustan Aristocracy|last=Syme|first=Ronald|publisher=Clarendon Press|year=1989|isbn=9780198147312|pages=149|edition=new, illustrated, reworked|series=Clarendon paperbacks|chapter=Two Nieces of Augustus}}</ref>


==References==

New page

{{Infobox military person
| name = Raja Rao Ranbha Bahadur
| native_name = राव रंभा निंबाळकर
| image = Procession of Raja Rao Ranbha Bahadur with Khushhal Khan.jpg
| caption = Raja Rao Ranbha in a grand military procession with Khushhal Khan "Anoop" (c. 1804).
| birth_name = Rambhaji Rao Nimbalkar
| honorific_suffix = [[Amir-ul-Umara]]
| death_date = c. 1804–1806
| death_place = [[Hyderabad State]]
| placeofburial = [[Moula Ali]], [[Hyderabad]]
| allegiance = [[Nizam of Hyderabad]]

| battles = [[Battle of Kolar]] (1781)<br>[[Battle of Pangal]] (1789)<br>[[Battle of Kharda]] (1795)
}}

'''Raja Rao Ranbha Bahadur''' (born '''Rambhaji Rao Nimbalkar'''; died c. 1804–1806) was a [[Maratha Empire|Maratha]] military commander and high-ranking nobleman active in the court of the [[Nizam of Hyderabad]] during the late 18th and early 19th centuries.<ref name="UPenn" /> He is historically recognized as a significant patron of the arts, particularly for commissioning the illustrated musical treatise ''[[Ragadarshan]]''.<ref name="UPenn" /> Holding the prestigious rank of ''[[Amir-ul-Umara]]'' (Commander of Commanders), he played a central role in the military maneuvers of the Hyderabad State during the transition to British subsidiary rule.<ref name="Schofield23" />

== Lineage and Early Life ==
Rao Ranbha belonged to the [[Nimbalkar]] dynasty, a Maratha clan that served as the Naiks of [[Phaltan]] before entering the service of the [[Nizams of Hyderabad]] in the early 18th century.<ref name="Gazetteer" /> His family established a "Maratha-Nizam" military tradition, leading large Hindu cavalry contingents within the [[Asaf Jahi dynasty|Asaf Jahi]] administration.<ref name="Gazetteer" />

== Career and Court Life ==
Raja Rao Ranbha served as a military commander within the [[Hyderabad State]].<ref name="UPenn" /> His military identity was defined by his command of a massive cavalry force, estimated at 20,000 men, which functioned as a private army within the state structure.<ref name="Schofield23" /> He was a constant fixture in the Nizam’s military campaigns, including the Battle of Kolar (1781) and the Battle of Pangal (1789).<ref name="Chaudhuri" />

His personal interests and courtly activities are preserved in a series of miniatures within the ''Rāg darshan'' manuscript, which depict him hunting on horseback with hounds, birds, and a cheetah, as well as observing horsemen and participating in courtly assemblies.<ref name="UPenn" /> He is frequently illustrated alongside contemporary figures such as the musician and author [[Khushhal Khan (musician)|Khushhāl Khān]].<ref name="UPenn" />

=== Battle of Kharda and Political Rise ===
In 1795, Rao Ranbha led his cavalry at the [[Battle of Kharda]] against the unified Maratha army.<ref name="Chaudhuri" /> Following the Nizam’s defeat and the subsequent hostage-taking of Prime Minister [[Arastu Jah]] to Pune, Ranbha's political influence reached its peak. In 1797, he was appointed as the '''Dewan''' (Prime Minister) of Hyderabad.<ref name="Briggs" /> However, upon Arastu Jah's return later that year, Ranbha was displaced as the state shifted toward a [[Subsidiary Alliance]] with the British.<ref name="Schofield23" />

=== Resistance to British Influence ===
Under the reign of [[Sikander Jah, Asaf Jah III]], Rao Ranbha became a central figure in the anti-British faction of the court.<ref name="Mallampalli" /> Alongside [[Raja Mahipat Ram]], he was suspected by the British Resident of engaging in "treasonous discussions" with British sepoys and attempting to persuade the Nizam to defy British authority.<ref name="Mallampalli" /> In 1806, under heavy pressure from Resident Sydenham, the Nizam was forced to dismiss and banish Ranbha from the court.<ref name="Chaudhuri" /><ref name="Rao2017" />

== Patronage of the Arts ==
In 1799, Ranbha commissioned Khushhāl Khān to author the ''Rāg darshan'', a theoretical work on the modes of [[Hindustani classical music]] written in the [[Dakhini]] language (using [[Nastaliq]]).<ref name="UPenn" /> The work is based on the fifth chapter of Mirza Khan's ''Tuḥfat al-hind''.<ref name="UPenn" />

The manuscript contains 52 miniatures completed by the court artist Haji Mir Ghulam Hasan by 1804.<ref name="UPenn" /> The iconography of these images follows the tradition of [[Amber, India|Amber]] in [[Rajasthan]] and utilises the Hanuman system of [[Raga]] classification.<ref name="UPenn" /> The work positioned Ranbha as a rightful heir to Mughal courtly sophistication during a period of political volatility.<ref name="SchofieldCh5" />

== Association with Mah Laqa Bai ==
[[File:Mah_Laqa_Bai_playing_Holi_detail_Ragadarshan.png|thumb|right|Mah Laqa Bai (left) and Raja Rao Ranbha (right) playing Holi. All three, including Khushhal Khan, are identified by inscriptions. From the ''Ragadarshan'' (c. 1804).]]
Raja Rao Ranbha was a major patron of the renowned poet and courtesan [[Mah Laqa Bai]] (also known as Māh-i Liqā or Chanda Bibi).<ref name="Schofield23" /> Their relationship was characterised by intellectual and cultural synergy; both were expert horse-riders and shared a passion for the hunt.<ref name="SchofieldCh5" /> The ''Rāg darshan'' manuscript serves as a primary visual record of their association, containing rare contemporary depictions of Mah Laqa Bai, including scenes showing the pair playing [[Holi]] (folio 23v) and Mah Laqa Bai performing a dance for the Raja (folio 24r).<ref name="UPenn" /><ref name="Schofield23" />

== Provenance of Commissioned Works ==
The ''Rāg darshan'' commissioned by Ranbha has a documented history of royal ownership. It was at one time held in the '''Anūpa Saṃskr̥ta Pustakālaya''' (the Bīkāner royal library) before entering private collections in the 20th century.<ref name="UPenn" /> In the 19th century, it was associated with [[Salar Jung III]] (Mir Yousuf Ali Khan).<ref name="UPenn" /> The manuscript was eventually donated to the [[University of Pennsylvania]] as part of the Lawrence J. Schoenberg Collection.<ref name="UPenn" />

== Death and Burial ==
Rao Ranbha died between 1804 and 1806 and was buried at the foot of the [[Moula Ali]] Hill in Hyderabad.<ref name="SchofieldCh5" /> He is buried in proximity to Khushhal Khan and Mah Laqa Bai.<ref name="Schofield23" />

== Gallery ==
<gallery>
File:Folio_23v_from_Ragadarshan_Mah_Laqa_Bai_playing_Holi.jpg|Full Folio 23v: Mah Laqa Bai and Raja Rao Ranbha playing Holi.
File:Mah_Laqa_Bai_dancing.jpg|Folio 24r: Chanda Bibi (Mah Laqa Bai) performing a dance for the Raja.
File:Mah_Laqa_Bai_singing.jpg|Folio 2v: Raja Rao Ranbha and Chanda Bibi (Mah Laqa Bai) with attendants.
</gallery>

== References ==
{{Reflist|refs=
<ref name="UPenn">{{cite web |title=Oversize LJS 63 Rāg darshan |url=https://find.library.upenn.edu/catalog/9949529953503681?hld_id=resource_link_1 |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Libraries |access-date=2026-02-08}}</ref>
<ref name="Schofield23">{{cite book |last=Schofield |first=Katherine Butler |title=Music and Musicians in Late Mughal India: Histories of the Ephemeral, 1748–1858 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2023 |isbn=9781108420624 |pages=119, 139}}</ref>
<ref name="SchofieldCh5">{{cite book |last=Schofield |first=Katherine Butler |chapter=Eclipsed by the Moon: Mahlaqa Bai and Khushhal Khan Anup in Nizami Hyderabad |title=Music and Musicians in Late Mughal India |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2023 |pages=117–146}}</ref>
<ref name="Gazetteer">{{cite web |title=NIZAM |url=https://gazetteers.maharashtra.gov.in/cultural.maharashtra.gov.in/english/gazetteer/aurangabad/CHAP02/NIZAM.htm |publisher=Maharashtra Gazetteers |access-date=2026-02-08}}</ref>
<ref name="Chaudhuri">{{cite thesis |last=Chaudhuri |first=Nani Gopal |title=British Relations with Hyderabad (1795-1857) |publisher=University of Calcutta |year=2016 |pages=49–54}}</ref>
<ref name="Briggs">{{cite book |last=Briggs |first=H.G. |title=The Nizam: His History and Relations with the British Government |volume=1 |publisher=Bernard Quaritch |year=1861 |pages=86–91}}</ref>
<ref name="Mallampalli">{{cite book |last=Mallampalli |first=C. |title=A Muslim Conspiracy in British India? Politics and Paranoia in Early Nineteenth Century Deccan |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2017 |isbn=9781108419215 |pages=74, 94}}</ref>
<ref name="Rao2017">{{cite book |last=Rao |first=Veldurti Manik |title=Freedom Struggle in Hyderabad |publisher=Publications Division, GOI |year=2017 |pages=54–55}}</ref>
}}

← Previous revision Revision as of 11:44, 8 February 2026
Line 119: Line 119:


=== Stafford Gambit: 3...Nc6?! <span class="anchor" id="Stafford Gambit"></span> ===
=== Stafford Gambit: 3...Nc6?! <span class="anchor" id="Stafford Gambit"></span> ===
Recently dubbed the Stafford Gambit, 3... Nc6{{chesspunc|?!}} is considered dubious, but it sets a number of [[List of chess traps|traps]]. It was advocated by [[Eric Rosen (chess player)|Eric Rosen]] in the early 2020s and became popular in online games. After 4.Nxc6 dxc6, White wins a pawn but must play carefully. After 5.e5 (5.d3 is better) Ne4 6.d3?? (White should play 6.Nc3, 6.d4, or 6.Qe2) 6...Bc5! and White resigned in Lowens–Stafford, US correspondence game 1950.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1243149 |title=Lowens vs. Stafford, 1950 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] }}</ref><ref>Forintos & Haág (1983), p. 110</ref> After 1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nf6 3.Nxe5 Nc6 4.Nxc6 dxc6 5.d3 Bc5, White must avoid the [[Légal Trap]] 6.Bg5?? Nxe4!, and if 7.Bxd8 (relatively best but still losing is 7.Be3) 7...Bxf2+ 8. Ke2 Bg4{{chessAN|#}}. Instead, White should play 6.Be2 Bc5 7.c3! with d3–d4 to follow, and Black has insufficient compensation for the pawn, though White must still play carefully.<ref>[[Avetik Grigoryan]], [https://chessmood.com/blog/stafford-gambit-the-refutation Stafford Gambit – The Refutation], Chessmood, 6 April, 2021</ref>
Recently dubbed the Stafford Gambit, 3... Nc6{{chesspunc|?!}} is considered dubious, but it sets a number of [[List of chess traps|traps]]. It was advocated by [[Eric Rosen (chess player)|Eric Rosen]] in the early 2020s and became popular in online games. After 4.Nxc6 dxc6, White wins a pawn but must play carefully. After 5.e5 (5.d3 is better) Ne4 6.d3?? (White should play 6.Nc3, 6.d4, or 6.Qe2) 6...Bc5! and White resigned in Lowens–Stafford, US correspondence game 1950.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1243149 |title=Lowens vs. Stafford, 1950 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] }}</ref><ref>Forintos & Haág (1983), p. 110</ref> After 1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nf6 3.Nxe5 Nc6 4.Nxc6 dxc6 5.d3 Bc5, White must avoid the [[Légal Trap]] 6.Bg5?? Nxe4!, and if 7.Bxd8 (relatively best but still losing is 7.Be3) 7...Bxf2+ 8. Ke2 Bg4{{chessAN|#}}. Instead, White should play 6.Be2 h5 7.c3! with d3–d4 to follow, and Black has insufficient compensation for the pawn, though White must still play carefully.<ref>[[Avetik Grigoryan]], [https://chessmood.com/blog/stafford-gambit-the-refutation Stafford Gambit – The Refutation], Chessmood, 6 April, 2021</ref>

|A derogatory racist slur that originated on the [[imageboard]], [[4chan]]. It is a fake name which combines the [[Punjabi language]]-honorific “Paaji” and [[Sikh names|Sikh firstnames]] ending in "-jeet". It is used online in some parts of America, the [[Western World]] and [[Islamic World|Muslim countries]] to target Indians, especially Sikhs, Hindus and even other South Asians.
|A derogatory racist slur that originated on the [[imageboard]], [[4chan]]. It is a fake name which combines the [[Punjabi language]]-honorific “Paaji” and [[Sikh names|Sikh firstnames]] ending in "-jeet". It is used online in some parts of America, the [[Western World]] and [[Islamic World|Muslim countries]] to target Indians, especially Sikhs, Hindus and even other South Asians.
|<ref name = 'PPCScroll'>{{cite news |url=https://scroll.in/article/1087921/pajeet-the-white-supremacist-slur-weaponised-by-south-asians-is-amplifying-anti-indian-hate |url-status=live |access-date=5 February 2026 |last=Chakrabartty |first=Partha P. |date=27 October 2025 |archive-url=https://archive.is/uHYk6 |archive-date=28 October 2025 |title=‘Pajeet’: The white supremacist slur weaponised by South Asians |quote=<br />The first known use of “Pajeet” dates to a July 2015 post on the 4chan internet message board. While it’s impossible to know what its coiner intended, a plausible theory is that it combines the Punjabi honorific “Paji” and names ending in -jeet, common among Sikhs.<br />The slur “Pajeet” targets Indians from all backgrounds, especially Sikh truck drivers. |publisher=[[Scroll.in]] }}</ref><ref name="GPAHE2024">{{cite web |date=8 May 2024 |title=Online Racism Targeting South Asians Skyrockets |url=https://globalextremism.org/post/online-racism-targeting-south-asians-skyrockets/ |access-date=25 September 2024 |publisher=Global Project Against Hate and Extremism |quote=“Pajeet” is also used, referring to a derogatory made-up Indian name originating on 4chan in 2015, along with several other similar, though sometimes lesser known, racist terms. Plenty of commenters resented “pajeet immigrants,” described as “barely literate third worlder[s],” for “replac[ing]” striking workers in the tech industry. One Canadian user on the /pol/ board claimed the “jeet situation” in Canada was bad, and that they planned to “leave this dump” because of South Asian immigrants. Gab, a “free speech” platform with a similar interface to Twitter, saw hate speech against South Asians rise from 197 posts in January 2023 to 691 the next year, representing a staggering 251 percent increase. Comments include calling South Asians “pajeet chimps” and “paki scum” while leaning into derogatory stereotypes such as saying “pajeet still smell.”}}</ref><ref name="Sudhakar2022">{{Cite book |last1=Sudhakar |first1=Prasiddha |url=https://millercenter.rutgers.edu/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/Hinduphobia-NC-Labs_6.22.22.pdf |title=Anti-Hindu Disinformation: A Case Study of Hinduphobia on Social Media |publisher=Rutgers University |quote=First seen on 4Chan, The term “pajeet” is an ethnic slur, coined as a derisive imitation of Indian names. Typically, pajeet is used to describe Indians on the Internet — and, by default — Hindus. John Earnest, the white supremacist shooter of the Chabad Synagogue in San Diego, 2019, had referenced “pajeets” in this manifesto. This slur has also been used by white supremacists in white nationalist podcasts in reference to violent, murderous fantasies about Indians.}}</ref><ref name = 'HinduTimesCanada'>{{Cite news |date=1 June 2023 |title=Racial slurs against Hindus have genocidal impact, says report |url=https://hindutimescanada.ca/racial-slurs-against-hindus-have-genocidal-impact-says-report/ |access-date=7 June 2025 |work=Hindu Times Canada |quote=''Pajeet'' is an extremely derogatory term often used interchangeably for Indians and Hindus.}}</ref><ref name="TNIE2024">{{cite web |date=27 March 2024 |title=Baltimore bridge collapse: Racist online attacks on Indian crew of MV Dali |url=https://www.newindianexpress.com/nation/2024/Mar/27/baltimore-bridge-collapse-racist-online-attacks-on-indian-crew-of-mv-dali |access-date=19 November 2024 |publisher=[[The New Indian Express]] |language=en |quote=Pajeet is a racist slur in the West to mock Sikhs who often have names ending with "jeet".}}</ref><ref name = 'D-FRAC>{{Cite web |last=Rana |first=Aayushi |date=March 13, 2024 |title=Cow Worshippers to Pajeets: Analysing the Lexicon of Dangerous Hate Speech Online |url=https://dfrac.org/en/2024/03/13/cow-worshippers-to-pajeets-analysing-the-lexicon-of-dangerous-hate-speech-online/ |access-date=18 January 2025 |website=Digital Forensics, Research and Analytics Centre (D-FRAC)}}</ref>
|<ref name = 'PPCScroll'>{{cite news |url=https://scroll.in/article/1087921/pajeet-the-white-supremacist-slur-weaponised-by-south-asians-is-amplifying-anti-indian-hate |url-status=live |access-date=5 February 2026 |last=Chakrabartty |first=Partha P. |date=27 October 2025 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20251028060615/https://scroll.in/article/1087921/pajeet-the-white-supremacist-slur-weaponised-by-south-asians-is-amplifying-anti-indian-hate |archive-date=28 October 2025 |title=‘Pajeet’: The white supremacist slur weaponised by South Asians |quote=<br />The first known use of “Pajeet” dates to a July 2015 post on the 4chan internet message board. While it’s impossible to know what its coiner intended, a plausible theory is that it combines the Punjabi honorific “Paji” and names ending in -jeet, common among Sikhs.<br />The slur “Pajeet” targets Indians from all backgrounds, especially Sikh truck drivers. |publisher=[[Scroll.in]] }}</ref><ref name="GPAHE2024">{{cite web |date=8 May 2024 |title=Online Racism Targeting South Asians Skyrockets |url=https://globalextremism.org/post/online-racism-targeting-south-asians-skyrockets/ |access-date=25 September 2024 |publisher=Global Project Against Hate and Extremism |quote=“Pajeet” is also used, referring to a derogatory made-up Indian name originating on 4chan in 2015, along with several other similar, though sometimes lesser known, racist terms. Plenty of commenters resented “pajeet immigrants,” described as “barely literate third worlder[s],” for “replac[ing]” striking workers in the tech industry. One Canadian user on the /pol/ board claimed the “jeet situation” in Canada was bad, and that they planned to “leave this dump” because of South Asian immigrants. Gab, a “free speech” platform with a similar interface to Twitter, saw hate speech against South Asians rise from 197 posts in January 2023 to 691 the next year, representing a staggering 251 percent increase. Comments include calling South Asians “pajeet chimps” and “paki scum” while leaning into derogatory stereotypes such as saying “pajeet still smell.”}}</ref><ref name="Sudhakar2022">{{Cite book |last1=Sudhakar |first1=Prasiddha |url=https://millercenter.rutgers.edu/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/Hinduphobia-NC-Labs_6.22.22.pdf |title=Anti-Hindu Disinformation: A Case Study of Hinduphobia on Social Media |publisher=Rutgers University |quote=First seen on 4Chan, The term “pajeet” is an ethnic slur, coined as a derisive imitation of Indian names. Typically, pajeet is used to describe Indians on the Internet — and, by default — Hindus. John Earnest, the white supremacist shooter of the Chabad Synagogue in San Diego, 2019, had referenced “pajeets” in this manifesto. This slur has also been used by white supremacists in white nationalist podcasts in reference to violent, murderous fantasies about Indians.}}</ref><ref name = 'HinduTimesCanada'>{{Cite news |date=1 June 2023 |title=Racial slurs against Hindus have genocidal impact, says report |url=https://hindutimescanada.ca/racial-slurs-against-hindus-have-genocidal-impact-says-report/ |access-date=7 June 2025 |work=Hindu Times Canada |quote=''Pajeet'' is an extremely derogatory term often used interchangeably for Indians and Hindus.}}</ref><ref name="TNIE2024">{{cite web |date=27 March 2024 |title=Baltimore bridge collapse: Racist online attacks on Indian crew of MV Dali |url=https://www.newindianexpress.com/nation/2024/Mar/27/baltimore-bridge-collapse-racist-online-attacks-on-indian-crew-of-mv-dali |access-date=19 November 2024 |publisher=[[The New Indian Express]] |language=en |quote=Pajeet is a racist slur in the West to mock Sikhs who often have names ending with "jeet".}}</ref><ref name = 'D-FRAC>{{Cite web |last=Rana |first=Aayushi |date=March 13, 2024 |title=Cow Worshippers to Pajeets: Analysing the Lexicon of Dangerous Hate Speech Online |url=https://dfrac.org/en/2024/03/13/cow-worshippers-to-pajeets-analysing-the-lexicon-of-dangerous-hate-speech-online/ |access-date=18 January 2025 |website=Digital Forensics, Research and Analytics Centre (D-FRAC)}}</ref>

The '''Christian persecution complex''' is the belief, attitude, or [[world view]] that Christian values and Christians are being oppressed by social groups and governments in the [[Western world]].<ref>{{harvnb|Hoover|2015|p=23}}: According to Hoover Linda "''...Castelli (2007) believed the reluctance to self-disclose could be the "Christian persecution complex" (p. 156), an ideology that Christian values are unfavorably targeted by social and governmental opposition...''"</ref> This belief is promoted by certain American Protestant churches,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/christians-in-the-us-are-not-persecuted-an-intersectional_b_59161b18e4b02d6199b2ef05|title=Christians In The U.S. Are Not Persecuted|last1=Kim|first1=Grace Ji-Sun|last2=Shaw|first2=Susan M.|date=2017-05-12|website=HuffPost|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190429130318/https://www.huffpost.com/entry/christians-in-the-us-are-not-persecuted-an-intersectional_b_59161b18e4b02d6199b2ef05 |archive-date=2019-04-29 |access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref> and some Christian- or Bible-based groups in Europe.<ref name=":0">{{harvnb|Hornback|2018|p=286}}: Afterword: White Nationalism, Trolling Humor as Propaganda, and the "Renaissance" of Christian Racism in the Age of Trump. "''In so doing, he, his speech writers, and advisors were pandering to the rising Christian white nationalist persecution complex in Poland and throughout Europe, giving voice to a message that Western Christianity—and Europeans—will defeat fundamentalist Islamism. He even concluded with an overt call to a modern-day Crusade: "So together, let us all fight like the Poles, for family, for freedom, for country, and for God."''"</ref> It has been called the "[[Evangelicalism in the United States|Evangelical]]",<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2014/08/the-evangelical-persecution-complex/375506/|title=Why Do Evangelicals Have a Persecution Complex?|last=Noble|first=Alan|date=2014-08-04|website=The Atlantic|language=en-US|access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref> "American Christian"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.christiantoday.com/article/are-american-christians-really-being-persecuted-or-are-they-just-being-manipulated/107522.htm|title=Are American Christians really being persecuted – or are they just being manipulated?|last=Cyzewski|first=Ed|date=2017-04-18|website=www.christiantoday.com|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180320170930/https://www.christiantoday.com/article/are-american-christians-really-being-persecuted-or-are-they-just-being-manipulated/107522.htm |archive-date=2018-03-20 |access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref> or "[[Christian right]]"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.salon.com/2015/07/05/the_raging_hypocrisy_at_the_center_of_the_christian_rights_persecution_complex/|title=The raging hypocrisy at the center of the Christian right's persecution complex|last=Neumann|first=Steve|date=2015-07-05|website=Salon|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706184201/http://www.salon.com:80/2015/07/05/the_raging_hypocrisy_at_the_center_of_the_christian_rights_persecution_complex/ |archive-date=2015-07-06 |access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref> persecution complex.
The '''Christian persecution complex''' is the belief, attitude, or [[worldview]] that Christian values and Christians are being oppressed by social groups and governments in the [[Western world]].<ref>{{harvnb|Hoover|2015|p=23}}: According to Hoover Linda "''...Castelli (2007) believed the reluctance to self-disclose could be the "Christian persecution complex" (p. 156), an ideology that Christian values are unfavorably targeted by social and governmental opposition...''"</ref> This belief is promoted by certain American [[Protestant]] churches,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/christians-in-the-us-are-not-persecuted-an-intersectional_b_59161b18e4b02d6199b2ef05|title=Christians In The U.S. Are Not Persecuted|last1=Kim|first1=Grace Ji-Sun|last2=Shaw|first2=Susan M.|date=2017-05-12|website=HuffPost|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190429130318/https://www.huffpost.com/entry/christians-in-the-us-are-not-persecuted-an-intersectional_b_59161b18e4b02d6199b2ef05 |archive-date=2019-04-29 |access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref> and some Christian- or Bible-based groups in Europe.<ref name=":0">{{harvnb|Hornback|2018|p=286}}: Afterword: White Nationalism, Trolling Humor as Propaganda, and the "Renaissance" of Christian Racism in the Age of Trump. "''In so doing, he, his speech writers, and advisors were pandering to the rising Christian white nationalist persecution complex in Poland and throughout Europe, giving voice to a message that Western Christianity—and Europeans—will defeat fundamentalist Islamism. He even concluded with an overt call to a modern-day Crusade: "So together, let us all fight like the Poles, for family, for freedom, for country, and for God."''"</ref> It has been called the "[[Evangelicalism in the United States|Evangelical]]",<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2014/08/the-evangelical-persecution-complex/375506/|title=Why Do Evangelicals Have a Persecution Complex?|last=Noble|first=Alan|date=2014-08-04|website=The Atlantic|language=en-US|access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref> "American Christian"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.christiantoday.com/article/are-american-christians-really-being-persecuted-or-are-they-just-being-manipulated/107522.htm|title=Are American Christians really being persecuted – or are they just being manipulated?|last=Cyzewski|first=Ed|date=2017-04-18|website=www.christiantoday.com|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180320170930/https://www.christiantoday.com/article/are-american-christians-really-being-persecuted-or-are-they-just-being-manipulated/107522.htm |archive-date=2018-03-20 |access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref> or "[[Christian right]]"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.salon.com/2015/07/05/the_raging_hypocrisy_at_the_center_of_the_christian_rights_persecution_complex/|title=The raging hypocrisy at the center of the Christian right's persecution complex|last=Neumann|first=Steve|date=2015-07-05|website=Salon|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706184201/http://www.salon.com:80/2015/07/05/the_raging_hypocrisy_at_the_center_of_the_christian_rights_persecution_complex/ |archive-date=2015-07-06 |access-date=2020-03-30}}</ref> persecution complex.


==Early Christianity==
==Early Christianity==


According to New Testament scholar [[Candida Moss]], the Christian "persecution complex" appeared during the era of [[early Christianity]] due to internal Christian [[identity politics]].<ref>{{harvnb|Janes|Houen|2014|p=24}}: Indeed, a recent study by Candida Moss, ''[[The Myth of Persecution]]'' has suggested that Christian "persecution complex" was the result of internal Christian identity politics.</ref> Moss suggested that the idea of persecution is cardinal to the worldview of Christianity, noting that it creates the impression that Christians are a minority that are facing a war{{snd}}even when they are numerically superior.<ref>{{harvnb|Årsheim|2016|p=7}}: Candida Moss has argued that the notion of persecution is all but essential to Christianity as a worldview, tracing the discursive construction of martyrdom from Antiquity and up to the present, pointing to its constitutive role for the self-understanding of Christians as embattled minorities{{snd}}even while numerically superior</ref> This perception is grounded in the belief that the world is divided into two factions, one led by [[God]] and the other by [[Satan]]. In this view, there can be no compromise between the two, and even attempting to dialogue or engage with "the other" is seen as a form of collaboration with it.<ref>{{harvnb|Moss|2013|p=254}}: The myth of persecution is theologically grounded in the division of the world into two parties, one backed by [[God]] and the other by [[Satan]]... And everyone knows you cannot reason with devil. Even when devil is not explicitly invoked, the rhetoric of persecution suggests that the persecutors are irrational and immoral and the persecuted are innocent and brave. In a world filled with persecution, efforts to negotiate or even reason with one's persecutors are interpreted as collaboration and moral compromise. We should not attempt to understand the other party, because to do so would be to cede ground to injustice and hatred</ref> Medieval historian Paul Cavill argues that the [[New Testament]] teaches that persecutions are inherent to Christianity.<ref>{{harvnb|Cavill|2013|p=81}}: The early Christian persecution complex is often underemphasised, but is important. The New Testament teaches that persecution is the inevitable by-product of effective Christianity.</ref>

In this view, there is no compromise between the two, and attempts at dialogue and engagement with "the other" are already seen as a form of collaboration with it.<ref>{{harvnb|Moss|2013|p=254}}: The myth of persecution is theologically grounded in the division of the world into two parties, one backed by [[God]] and the other by [[Satan]]... The New Testament teaches that persecution is the inevitable by-product of effective Christianity.</ref>

"''Scholars and journalists alike have identified an "evangelical persecution complex" in our culture. This term unfairly stigmatizes all evangelicals but identifies a widely shared sensitivity. Some Christians major in the persecution complex, even to the point of associating florists who will not serve same-sex couples with actual Christian martyrs in the Middle East.24 Recent films like God's Not Dead and God's Not Dead 2 imagine embattled Christians prevailing against entrenched secularist opposition''". That explains the film critique that was mentioned above.</ref> In 2018, David Ehrlich, a film critic, described how the persecution complex is fueled by films and media such as the [[God's Not Dead (film series)|''God's Not Dead'']] saga.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.indiewire.com/2018/03/gods-not-dead-a-light-in-the-darkness-review-1201944793/|title='God's Not Dead: A Light in the Darkness' Review: A Hellishly Bad Drama About America's Christian Persecution Complex|last=Ehrlich|first=David|date=2018-03-29|website=IndieWire|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180401025029/http://www.indiewire.com:80/2018/03/gods-not-dead-a-light-in-the-darkness-review-1201944793/ |archive-date=2018-04-01 |access-date=2018-12-10|quote=Whereas other recent offerings like "Heaven Is for Real" and last week's "I Can Only Imagine" are largely harmless in how they preach to the choir and prostrate themselves before Evangelical audiences, Pure Flix's "God's Not Dead" saga has been defined by a persecution complex large enough to crucify Christ the Redeemer.}}</ref>
